awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Learning to Use Essential Tools and Resources for Data Science with a Cloud-Based Virtual Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Business, government, and science researchers are producing massive amounts of complex data. The availability of these huge datasets fuels a need for both data-driven analytics and a 21st-century workforce that can use data analytics to answer questions and solve problems. This collaborative project will develop a cloud-based virtual platform to train undergraduate students how to use software tools essential to data science. The platform will make state-of-the-art computing resources, including both powerful data analysis tools and parallel hardware systems, more accessible to students and faculty, even if they are at institutions without locally available high-power computing systems.  The project aims to help students develop critical workforce skills in data science. The project will also provide professional development opportunities to help faculty use data-analysis tools in their courses and research.

The goal of this project is to develop a cloud-based infrastructure in the form of a virtual science platform with related training modules. First, it will leverage an existing framework for building web applications to provide broad access to open source, high performance computing resources at the collaborating universities and through the NSF Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment. The cloud-based platform will support both training of students and collaboration among students. Second, the project will produce a data science curriculum targeted to undergraduate students. The curriculum will also be suitable for graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, and information technology professionals interested in data science. The project will deliver a full set of interactive documents and video tutorials on using and configuring the platform. The educational activities will use graphical, interactive, simulation-based, and experiential learning components to teach data science concepts and computing skills, accessed through the cloud-based platform. Through the platform, students will have the opportunity to learn how to use powerful data science resources, enabling their potential to transform data-rich computer science and engineering problems into practical solutions. Third, the project will deliver professional development for faculty at multiple institutions, to help them learn how to use data science in their classrooms and their own research. This project addresses national interests by making state-of-the-art computing resources more accessible to students, supporting their development of critical workforce skills.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the project is to support the education of methods and tools of data science using remote computing environments. As big data analysis and advanced machine learning algorithms drastically increasing computing resource requirement, high performance computing (HPC) resources are actively adopted by wide variety domain fields. How to improve the accessibility and support of educational tasks on HPC have become an emerging problem for supercomputing centers. To address these challenges, the project team from the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) and the University of Louisville (UofL) has developed a user driven web application framework to help training and accessing essential tools for data science with remote high-performance computing resources; training materials on how to use R, machine learning and deep learning tools on HPC resources; and multiple training workshops, tutorials and curriculum course development.

During the project period, the project team has developed a user driven web application framework (IDOLS, https://idols.tacc.utexas.edu/) empower users to design, customize, and practice different analytics workflows, including R-based analytics workflows, through simple configurations on web and pre-built task modules to access remote high-performance hardware and software resources. With IDOLS, analytic workflow and application can run on remote resources as a webservice in a shareable and re-usable fashion. IDOLS allowed educators to utilize its data-analysis and parallel computing tools as active learning modules in various educational settings.

Although there are a number of tools useful for general data sciences, we focused on training around using R, SPARK, Python and Tensorflow in this project and has developed corresponding training modules for these tools. Each training module is designed for one-day workshop format and includes slide presentations, code examples and exercises. In addition to these general tools, the project also enabled training material development on specific topics, including for video content analysis, speech recognition and natural language processing for targeted communities.

The training materials and tools are essential parts of the week-long Machine Learning Institute organized by PI and hosted at Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) every summer since 2017 (https://www.tacc.utexas.edu/education/institutes/machine-learning). Each institute drew about 50 students and researchers from diverse domain fields to learn about how effectively running data analysis and machine learning tools on TACC resources. Additionally, the PI has also organized half day tutorial which focus on distributed deep learnings with HPC during the Supercomputing conference (SC) annually since 2018. The tutorial at SC attracted near 100 participants each year.  The parallel computing modules in the platform has been adopted in the lectures of PI Zhang's software engineering class (CSE 550) at University of Louisville (UofL) to introduce parallel processing architecture and parallel computing in scientific software systems.

The project provided substantive educational opportunities for students.  At TACC site, the project has provided research and development experiences for three undergraduate students. At Lousville site, 3 phd students through the research and development of this project, training opportunities for 1 KY high school science teacher through 2018 RET summer program, and 1 non-UofL undergraduate student through 2021 RUE summer program. From both TACC and UofL, work under this grant also contributed to 13 publications including 11 conference papers and presentations, 2 journal articles, and thesis being developed that contain specific results from the project.

This project addresses national interests by making state-of-the-art computing resources more accessible to students, supporting their development of critical workforce skills. The general project indicates the cloud-based environment can deliver software tools in ways that meet community needs and lower the barriers for students and researchers to use advanced computing systems and can naturally facilitate the integration of education and research. These findings influenced the educational framework and materials developed in the project. The project also introduces a potential new paradigm to perform data-intensive and compute-intensive research, by empowering scientists and researchers with a simple yet powerful web-based interface to perform data-intensive analytics workflow and large-scale simulations by utilizing remote resources.
